description: Motorola is hoping the Moto E can attract budget-conscious shoppers wary of two-year contracts.
title: Have $129? Motorola Has a Contract-Free Smartphone For You
title_page: Have $129? Motorola Has a Contract-Free Smartphone For You
text:
Unlocked top-of-the-line phones are expensive. The iPhone 5s with 16GB of memory costs $649 without a contract. The upside? Consumers are free to shop around for the cheapest service plan and don’t get hit with huge fees if they decide to switch to something else.
Of course, plenty of people are willing to tolerate restrictive plans and poor customer service if it means a $200 subsidized iPhone.
The Moto E is not the most advanced alternative. Still, it’s no schlub. It runs the latest version of Android, KitKat, and features a scratch-resistant, 4.3-inch Corning Gorilla Glass display, 5-megapixel rear camera, 1.2GHz dual-core processor and interchangeable color shells.
Sadly, it lacks a front-facing camera, which is bad news for people who love taking selfies, and its 960 by 540 pixel resolution won't impress many people.
None of its features are revolutionary, but, again, the phone costs only $129. Motorola, soon to switch hands from Google to Lenovo, is marketing the Moto E as “made to last, priced for all.” Consumers could decide that is all they need to ditch two-year contracts.
